Description: Corroded iron large knife, with a wide leaf-shaped blade and a narrow tang with rectangular cross-section, ending with a flattened circular or semi-circular pommel. Traces of the wooden haft are visible on the rusted surface of the tang and the base of the blade. The haft's head was rounded and partly covering the base of the blade on both sides, where the handle slabs were fastened by three nonaligned rivets. Two other rivets were fixing the slabs on the tang, one still protruding on one side. The haft had certainly a shape splaying near the blade.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, "Qasr", east annex (C), chamber 19 A
Dimensions: Thickness: 2 centimetres (haft; original thickness deduced from the rivet.)
Curator's comments: See partic. W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 78 § 78 : " The large double-edged knife (fig. 6) is a splendid specimen in perfect condition, found in chamber 19A; the grain of the wood on the handle is very plain , both the cross-piece on the haft of the blade fastened with 3 rivets, and the handle itself fastened by 2 rivets". Found with 3 pokers (of which one is London, BM, EA 23944).
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p.56 § 55, p. 78 § 78, p. 110, pl. xxxviii, 6)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.46, p.74, p.76, p.184, pl.26)
Condition: Corroded, broken into three pieces (blade, tang an part of pommel); fragments of the pommel are missing.
